Experts at agroecology summit call for collaboration to build sustainable food systems
Leaders from government, IFAD, and the agri-sector convened to discuss how ecological practices and farmer-led enterprises can build resilience, inclusivity, and shared prosperity in India’s agriculture.
New Delhi, November 6:
Empowering Smallholders through Sustainability
Delivering the keynote address, Dr. Devesh Chaturvedi, Secretary, Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers’ Welfare, Government of India, underscored India’s commitment to empowering smallholders through sustainable and collective enterprise models.

“Agroecology offers not just sustainability but shared prosperity by empowering farmers, restoring ecosystems, and strengthening markets,” he remarked. “Through the GAP Fund, managed by ACCESS Development Services, IFAD is proud to accelerate smallholder farming as part of the global agroecological transformation.”
Other eminent speakers included Sanjeev Asthana, Chairman, ACCESS Development Services and CEO, Patanjali Foods; Pravesh Sharma, Chairman, Samunnati Foundation; Vivek Sinha, Lead – GAP Fund, ACCESS Development Services; and Vipin Sharma, CEO, ACCESS Development Services.

These studies provide actionable insights to strengthen market linkages, reduce post-harvest losses, and promote local-level value addition. Drawing on national datasets, field consultations, and secondary research, the reports emphasize that despite agriculture contributing over 17% of India’s Gross Value Added and supporting nearly half of the population, small and marginal farmers continue to face systemic challenges such as fragmented value chains, limited processing capacity, and high post-harvest losses, particularly in perishables.
“Agroecology represents the future of Indian agriculture anchored in ecological balance and economic resilience,” said Vipin Sharma, CEO, ACCESS Development Services. “Through initiatives like the GAP Fund, we are showing that ecological enterprises can grow commercially while restoring natural resources and strengthening livelihoods.”
Recognising Innovation in Agroecology
The summit also featured a Grantees Award Ceremony, honouring enterprises demonstrating innovation and impact in advancing agroecology-led business models.
A series of expert-led discussions explored themes such as “Programmes Driving Agroecology: Opportunities, Challenges and Way Forward,” “Beyond Labels: Are Certifications Enough to Drive Real Change in Agro-Food Systems?” “Agroecology as a Pathway to Climate Resilience and Food Sovereignty,” and “Sustainability Beyond Catalytic Funding – Do Agroecology Projects Make Business Sense?”
A Roadmap for Mainstreaming Agroecology
Through these deliberations, the summit underscored ACCESS Development Services’ threefold mission—to showcase successful agroecology-based models, bridge gaps through collaboration, and co-create a national roadmap for scaling sustainable business models.
